articles.headline: Company in Bangladesh Agrees to Union Peace
articles.snippet: Several Western companies cut off orders to the Azim Group after union leaders were assaulted outside its factories.
articles.abstract: Several Western companies cut off orders to the Azim Group after union leaders were assaulted outside its factories.
articles.lead_paragraph: After wielding intense pressure against a Bangladeshi apparel maker over assaults on union leaders outside its factories, Western companies have agreed to resume business with that manufacturer, on the condition that it stay committed to halting further violence and make peace with its labor unions.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: From a Private School in Cairo to ISIS Killing Fields in Syria (With Video)
articles.snippet: The West is not alone in struggling to understand why young men like Islam Yaken, raised in homes that would never condone violence, are joining the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: The West is not alone in struggling to understand why young men like Islam Yaken, raised in homes that would never condone violence, are joining the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — He winced at the mere mention of his son’s name, visibly overcome by an unceasing thought that he struggled to articulate. He looked down to hide the tears in his eyes.

articles.headline: Fed Appears to Hesitate on Raising Interest Rate
articles.snippet: Some officials were concerned that raising rates prematurely might threaten the apparent economic recovery.
articles.abstract: Some officials were concerned that raising rates prematurely might threaten the apparent economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is not sounding like an institution that is ready to raise its benchmark interest rate in June.

articles.headline: Two Deals Bring Attention to Banking’s Safra Family
articles.snippet: The Safra Group, headed by Joseph Safra, recently bought Chiquita Brands International, the fruit company, and the London office tower known as the Gherkin.
articles.abstract: The Safra Group, headed by Joseph Safra, recently bought Chiquita Brands International, the fruit company, and the London office tower known as the Gherkin.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a single day last fall, two deals were coming together that would draw unusual attention to a banking family that prefers to remain in the shadows.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Dan Horch

articles.headline: Unlikely Cause Unites the Left and the Right: Justice Reform
articles.snippet: Groups like Koch Industries and the Center for American Progress, usually bitter adversaries, are banding together to reduce prison populations and overhaul sentencing.
articles.abstract: Groups like Koch Industries and the Center for American Progress, usually bitter adversaries, are banding together to reduce prison populations and overhaul sentencing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Usually bitter adversaries, Koch Industries and the Center for American Progress have found at least one thing they can agree on: The nation’s criminal justice system is broken.

articles.headline: Faulted for Avoiding ‘Islamic’ Labels to Describe Terrorism, White House Cites a Strategic Logic
articles.snippet: With remarkable consistency, President Obama and his aides have favored bland, generic terms over anything that explicitly connects attacks or plots to Islam.
articles.abstract: With remarkable consistency, President Obama and his aides have favored bland, generic terms over anything that explicitly connects attacks or plots to Islam.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama chooses his words with particular care when he addresses the volatile connections between religion and terrorism. He and his aides have avoided labeling acts of brutal violence by Al Qaeda, the so-called Islamic State and their allies as “Muslim” terrorism or describing their ideology as “Islamic” or “jihadist.”

articles.headline: Greece’s Request for Loan Extension Is Rejected by Germany
articles.snippet: The country is trying to negotiate an agreement before a Friday deadline imposed by eurozone finance ministers.
articles.abstract: The country is trying to negotiate an agreement before a Friday deadline imposed by eurozone finance ministers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Greece is headed toward a potentially destructive standoff with Europe after Germany rejected a last-minute request on Thursday to extend its loan program.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: Walmart Raising Wage to at Least $9
articles.snippet: Facing a tighter job market, employee turnover and scrutiny of its labor practices, the retailer plans to increase pay for a half-million workers.
articles.abstract: Facing a tighter job market, employee turnover and scrutiny of its labor practices, the retailer plans to increase pay for a half-million workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walmart, the largest private employer in the country, said on Thursday that it would increase wages for a half-million employees, a move that comes amid persistent scrutiny of its labor practices and high employee turnover.

articles.headline: New Rules Spur a Humbling Overhaul of Wall St. Banks
articles.snippet: Wall Street is in a transformation, as bonuses shrink, revenue growth stalls and business lines are cut, driven primarily by regulatory efforts.
articles.abstract: Wall Street is in a transformation, as bonuses shrink, revenue growth stalls and business lines are cut, driven primarily by regulatory efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly seven years after the financial crisis, banks are still churning out profits and wrestling with regulators.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Peter Eavis
